ReferralArticle8: Your PCP also communicates with any specialists you may see to ensure you receive proper care. Remember, however, that a specialist cannot refer you to another specialist. In this type of plan, all referrals need to be coordinated by your PCP.
ReferralArticle9: If you do need a specialist, he or she can provide your PCP with an immediate electronic transfer of all test and lab results. For example, your file may contain an existing imaging record or lab test that, if unnoticed, could result in unnecessary radiation exposure and repetitious imaging and lab work.
ReferralArticle11: Because your PCP takes on the primary responsibility for coordinating and managing all of your health care, he or she becomes the qualified expert when determining whether a referral is appropriate.
ReferralArticle12: For example, a throbbing ear isn't always an indication that you need to see an ear, nose, and throat (ENT) specialist – even the worst ear infection may be effectively treated with oral or topical antibiotics via a prescription from your PCP without making an appointment with a specialist, saving you time and money. Suffering from chronic ear pain that doesn’t respond to antibiotics, however, may warrant a PCP referral to an ENT specialist who's an expert on the latest treatments.
ReferralArticle13: On the other hand, it's important to note that you'll need to make an appointment with your PCP first, even if you think you would like to see a specialist right away. This may mean extra visits to the doctor.
ReferralArticle15: How do you know which specialty and provider are appropriate for your care? By combining networks, location, medical training, and compatibility with your symptoms, your PCP can send you to the right specialist when you need one. This saves you time and money that will no longer be spent on needless office visits, prescriptions or treatments.
ReferralArticle16: However, if you want more control over which specialists you see and when, a referral-required plan may not be right for you. Your PCP, sometimes referred to as a "gatekeeper" functions as your plan coordinator, determining what specialists, if any, you can see and in what order.
ReferralArticle17: Whether or not a referral is required for your health plan, it's important to understand how different insurance policies work so you can select the right healthcare for you and your family.
ProviderHeader: What you should know about provider networks
ProviderArticle1: To help you better understand what you should know about provider networks, let’s begin by defining what providers and networks are.
ProviderArticle2: A provider includes doctors, hospitals, labs, pharmacies, and other health care institutions. A provider has the education, certification, and experience to serve patients in their medical needs.
ProviderArticle3: A network is a group of providers that your insurance plan pre-selects to contract with. Providers must meet the plan's criteria and quality of standards in order to be part of the group. This includes certification, geography, and rates.
ProviderArticle9: If you're ready to do your homework, here's a guide to making decisions about your provider network.
ArticleTitleLife: See how Life Insurance helped protect a family's assets (3-minutes)
ProviderArticle5: Provider networks save on costs because the insurer pre-negotiates lower rates in exchange for driving volume to the providers. An in-network plan only covers costs for doctors in the associated provider network. Provider networks enable you to choose doctors and facilities with which your out-of-pocket expenses will be smallest.
ProviderArticle6: Moreover, by signing up for in-network-only plans, you can save consistently on your monthly insurance premiums, since in-network-only plans trade restriction to network-only providers for lower costs to plan participants. In fact, recent health care trends include the growth of such plans, as they provide even greater cost savings.
ProviderArticle7: Physicians in provider networks are screened by the carrier to meet certain criteria, meaning that you can more easily put your faith in the people who manage your care. Also, a lot of paperwork is taken care of for you, since in-network providers typically refer you to other in-network providers, saving you time and money.
ProviderArticle10: First, make a list of your current doctors, therapists, pharmacies, and health conditions. Then, play matchmaker as you look for a compatible network. Key questions to ask and answer when evaluating a plan's network are:
ProviderArticle11: What doctors are in the network? In addition to your primary care physician, don't forget about any specialists who are important to you and your family, such as optometrists and orthodontists.
ArticleTitleDisability: See how Disability insurance helped protect Ashley's income (3-minutes)
fowFailProductDependency: If you want to sign up for {0}, you {1} sign up for {2}.
ProviderArticle12: What medical facilities are in the network? Consider urgent care, therapy, imaging, prescriptions, and lab work — including anything from yearly blood work for your cholesterol screening to a toddler's Friday night ear infection.
ProviderArticle13: How broad is the network? There are both broad and limited choices when it comes to networks, which will impact the number of choices you have when it comes to medical specialists, where they are located, deductibles, etc. See if you are satisfied with the options in your plan by starting with a particular specialty. For example, how many child orthodontists are available to you?
ProviderArticle14: Finally, since carriers have different networks, often of various sizes, (and sometimes multiple networks within each plan), it's always a good to review all provider networks that you might be considering.
ProviderArticle15: The good news is that the tradeoff — between the freedom to choose any provider and facility versus paying a lower premium and out-of-pocket cost within a provider network — gives everyone a choice in their health care.

LifestyleArticle1: From jet setters to soccer moms, everyone has a financial lifestyle that they've grown accustomed to and that could be severely hampered if unexpected costs arose. While the actual "things" that insurance covers are very important — from our health and wellbeing to our property — here, we'll explore some misconceptions about insurance and how we got to where we are today. The reality is, insurance is about financial protection, not about protecting your health or property.
LifestyleArticle3: The concept of insurance has been in existence long before people spent a lot of money on houses and cars — and on their medical bills. It started as early as 4000 BC when shipping merchants were granted loans that had to be paid back as long as the shipment arrived at its destination safely. If the shipment was lost at sea the loan did not have to be repaid. A later form of insurance developed in ancient Rome around 600 BC, in which societies contributed to a pool of costs that would be utilized by individual members, as needed, for burial expenses. Over the centuries, however, as various industries began offering insurance beyond maritime contracts and burial trusts and competing with one another for customers, the role insurance plays in our protection shifted.
LifestyleArticle5: It's easy to understand why we've gotten away from the idea of insurance as financial protection in modern times. Some insurance plans have evolved to consist of pre-payment for services like preventive care visits (e.g., mammograms, colonoscopies, and annual physicals). Dental and vision insurance typically have a very low annual cap on coverage, since they often pay for preventive services such as cleanings and basic eye exams. If you have a significant expense like root canal or cataracts, however — you're likely to be on the hook for more than you might think.
CoverageMaximumExceededText: You are not eligible for this item because the calculated coverage amount exceeds the allowed maximum.
LifestyleArticle6: Accidents and medical issues are difficult enough to endure without having to worry about financial burdens. Yes, insurance is about money; more specifically, protecting your income and your savings should unforeseen expenses occur.
LifestyleArticle8: One type of insurance that works as financial protection is car insurance — we don't expect to file a claim every time we need new tires or a tune up, the equivalent of preventive services for your car. However, when we're in a car accident, we welcome having insurance that will cover the cost of repairs or even a new car.
fowFailProductTypeDependency: If you want to sign up for a {0} {1} plan{2}, you {3} sign up for a {4} {5} plan{6}.
LifestyleArticle9: That's really how the concept of insurance was designed to work. Yet, we expect our medical insurance to cover every visit to a doctor; when in reality, the opposite paradigm should be in effect. We should be paying for the "little things," knowing the "big things" are covered by our insurance. This is what gives us peace of mind.
LifestyleArticle10: That's precisely what insurance was developed for — having the financial protection you need should something serious happen. Take, for example, two forms of supplemental insurance: critical illness and accident insurance. In the case that you're covered and either is activated — you're diagnosed with a serious illness or in a major accident — you can file a claim and you are paid in a lump sum when you absolutely need it. Another exception to the current model is life insurance. With life insurance, you pay in for services that you may never use, but that would become extremely important should the need ever arise.
CoverageTierDependentMismatchText: You are not eligible for this item because you do not have the type of dependents or amount of dependents needed for this product coverage tier.
LifestyleArticle11: Conversely, a system of receiving smaller payments over a period of time for various checkups or aches and pains can actually lead to over-utilization of medical care, with people thinking they should visit the doctor more often than necessary, because "it's covered by my insurance."
LifestyleArticle12: With this background and knowledge in mind, how well is your current insurance working to protect your financial lifestyle? Are there areas where you could use additional insurance to gain peace of mind?
ReferralHeader: Learn more about health plans that require referrals
ReferralArticle5: Wondering about more advantages and disadvantage of a referral-based health plan? Here a few important points to consider:
ReferralArticle1: A referral is authorization from your primary care physician (PCP) for you to see a specialist and may be required by some health care plans. By enlisting your PCP, this type of pre-approval allows your doctor to coordinate your care. In this type of plan, one doctor oversees your care and coordinates with a team of specialists to help you get any additional care you may need.
ReferralArticle2: Sometimes called a "gatekeeper," your PCP refers you to specialists whose opinions he or she trusts in their respective fields – this is your PCP's "referral circle." The advantage of a referral in this case, is that you can have faith you’re seeing someone selected by a physician you have a relationship with.
ReferralArticle3: By ensuring that you get the care you need from the appropriate provider (PCP vs. specialist), your insurance company lowers their costs and can pass on those savings to you in the form of lower premiums and on-going expenses.
ReferralArticle4: Since your PCP coordinates all of your health care needs, be sure to check with him or her before seeing health care professionals outside of your network. Once you have a referral in hand, you can be certain that the care you receive from the specialist is now eligible for insurance coverage under your policy. It's also important to note that without a referral from your PCP, you’ll have to pay all costs for your treatment. Exceptions to this rule are sometimes made for emergencies.
ReferralArticle7: Your PCP can be a primary source when it comes to consolidating and coordinating all of your medical care. Certain health conditions can be diagnosed only with a complete view of your symptoms, and while a single isolated symptom may not be cause for alarm, a PCP's ability to recognize a set of symptoms could be critical for a timely diagnosis and effective treatment.

RiskArticle2: People are unduly influenced by psychological factors when it comes to their perception of risk. For example, if a plane randomly crashes and makes headlines, our perception of flying the next day may be affected negatively. We may be more afraid to fly — when in reality, the chances of a plane crashing the day following a random accident are no more or less than they were the day prior to the accident. Still, our perceptions largely govern our actions and we may cancel our flight.
RiskArticle3: This is an example of what psychologists call the influence of "dread." If an act generates fear, our sense of risk rises. Hearing news of a painful death makes people willing to pay more to insure against the risk of dying the same way. It's a gut level reaction that guides our perceptions.
RiskArticle5: So how do we gauge the true risks in life?
RiskArticle7: Here is a list of the most common risks people face in life order of their likelihood of occurring.
RiskArticle30: Contact with hornets, wasps and bees
RiskArticle4: Overestimating risk is also evident when the "recency" factor is at play. We tend to be more cautious when negative events and consequences are fresh in our minds, and may pay more to insure ourselves based on these feelings as a result. A 1993 study found that fears ignited after a terrorist attack caused more people to take out airline insurance with clauses that covered "terrorist acts" over "all possible causes." Logically, this makes no sense because "all possible causes" includes terrorist acts, but our fear sometimes drives us to make illogical decisions.
RiskArticle6: Awareness of our own reactions to tragedies and how we internalize them is our best resource for guarding against feelings of dread influencing our approach to risk. While statistics may vary from year to year, and mean very little when something actually happens to us or someone we love, it helps to stay abreast of individual various risk factors for disease and take precautions to keep ourselves and our loved ones safe.
RiskArticle27: Exposure to electric current, radiation, temperature and pressure
RiskArticle29: Contact with heat and hot substances
RiskArticle34: How much is the way you perceive risk influenced by fear and dread and how much by true risk factors? Once you know the true risks in life, can you ensure that you and your family are protected against them with the right insurance.
RiskArticle35: Risk: The Science and Politics of Fear, Virgin Books, 2008.

advPelcText: Excess personal liability coverage protects your assets and future earnings in the event that you or your family are held legally liable for an accident involving bodily injury or property damage, or if you are sued for personal injury.
advPelcModalText: Excess personal liability, or umbrella, coverage protects your assets and future earnings in the event that you or your family are held legally liable for an accident involving bodily injury or property damage, or if you are sued for personal injury. This coverage can be much more cost effective and convenient to purchase through a group program than if it is purchased individually. We recommend purchasing a limit that protects your total personal assets. You should consider purchasing additional coverage if you have higher liability risk-factors, such as youthful drivers in your household, recreational vehicles, watercraft, swimming pools, hot tubs, trampolines, multiple homes and autos, tenant-occupied homes, higher-risk dog breeds, and horses.

advEAPModal: An Employee Assistance Program (EAP) offers free, confidential services to help you address everyday challenges and issues that may affect your job performance, health, mental, and emotional well-being. Services may include confidential counseling and referrals; financial information and resources; expert information regarding relationships, work, children; legal support; health care navigation; and more. EAP services help you gain support, resources and information before these issues have a detrimental effect on you and your family.
advEmployerPaidLifeModalText:
Life insurance is a financial tool that helps you safeguard your family's future. Your employer will pay monthly premiums to an insurance company that agrees to pay a specific amount to your designated beneficiaries in the event of your death. You can name a primary beneficiary and a contingent beneficiary who would receive benefits if the primary beneficiary dies before you do.


With Life insurance, you ensure financial resources that go toward:


• Final medical expenses
• Funeral and burial costs
• Mortgage, housing and other bills related to daily life

Time may be purchased in increments of half or full days, up to a maximum set by your employer. Some employers may allow pre-tax dollars to be applied to this benefit for an additional savings.
advHealthCareCostsModalText: Within your geographic area, you could have many options to choose from when looking for a health care provider for common procedures and tests. Whether you are spending money out of pocket, or some of your HSA or FSA funds, it's important to find the facilities with access to the most cost-effective and high-quality tools that are the best fit for the services you need. A health care transparency tool will let you view standard prices for procedures and tests and compare these prices across multiple providers in your area. This will allow you to make the best possible decision for your health and for your wallet.

advVisionModalText:
Vision insurance may cover regular eye exams, updating prescriptions, and payments toward eyeglasses or contact lenses. Vision plans vary by network size and options, required copays and coinsurance, and even discounts offered.

A medical plan typically covers eye problems, such as:

• An injury or infection
• Glaucoma
• A detached retina


However, you need a vision plan to cover what most medical options don’t, including:

• Exams to determine your eyeglass prescription and detect vision problems
• Corrective eyeglass lenses (and/or contact lenses with some plans)
• Eyeglass frames


If you will need new eyeglasses or contacts in the upcoming year, you should consider a vision plan.
AdvTelemedicineModalText: Telemedicine provides access to consultation with a physician 24/7, by phone or email, to discuss symptoms, recommend treatment options, diagnose common conditions, and prescribe medication when appropriate.
advHealthCoachModalText: A Health Coaching plan may provide you with online wellness services to even an experienced coach to guide and encourage you in achieving health goals such as weight loss, smoking cessation, or regular exercise depending on the offering. Please note that the number of coaching sessions covered by phone or email, as well as the number of services provided, can vary greatly by plan.
SalaryAllocationContribution: Your Employer is contributing {0:C2} toward your benefits portfolio based on your salary.
advHealthSavingsModalText:
A Health Savings Account (HSA) works with your medical plan to help you offset uncovered costs while enjoying a tax benefit. An HSA can only be selected if your medical plan qualifies for this type of account. These plans will be marked as HSA qualified on the Shop page. You can decide how much to contribute to your HSA each year, up to a maximum amount set by the Internal Revenue Service (IRS). Your contributions go into your HSA account tax-free and you’re also reimbursed tax-free for eligible expenses.


Some benefits of an HSA include:


• While your money remains in your HSA account, it earns tax-free investment returns
• Any funds left in your HSA at the end of the year remain invested and can be rolled over from year-to-year
• You can keep your HSA account even if you change jobs or retire, making an HSA a great way to save for medical costs in retirement


Consult the IRS website for the most up-to-date information on HSA rules, limits, and covered expenses.
advDependentFSAModalText:
A Child Care Flexible Savings Account (FSA) enables you to set up weekly payroll deductions, tax free, that can be used to cover expenses for looking after your child while you are at work or school. Costs for babysitting, daycare, and even sleep away camp may be covered.

You should carefully calculate your expected child care expenses this year, as only a portion of these funds can be rolled over to the following year.
cuFile: File Attachment (less than 2 MB in size):
advMedicalFSAModalText:
A Medical FSA gives you a tax break on money you set aside for your family’s health care bills. The IRS permits pre-tax Medical FSA contributions. As you and your family receive health care, you file claims and are reimbursed with tax-free funds from your Medical FSA for qualified expenses, such as copays, coinsurance, and deductibles.


There are limits established by the IRS as to how much you can contribute to your FSA. Unlike with an HSA account, only limited amounts can be rolled over , although new rules are making limited amounts transferable if used within a certain time period the following year, subject to your employer’s approval.


Be sure to estimate the amount of qualified spending you’re likely to have in a year if you opt for a Medical FSA.

Consult the IRS website for the most up-to-date information on Medical FSA rules, limits and covered expenses.
advChildLifeModalText:
Child Life insurance is a tool that helps protect you financially in the event on the unthinkable. To buy Child Life insurance, you pay monthly premiums to an insurance company that agrees to pay a specific amount in the event of the death of your child.


With Child Life insurance you can ensure financial resources that go toward:


• Final medical expenses
• Funeral and burial expenses
ProviderToolQuestion: Are there certain doctors, hospitals, or other health care providers that you want in your network?
ProviderToolStep1Text: Use the provider lookup tool to confirm your doctors and health care providers are part of the covered networks.
advTransitFSAModalText:
A Transit FSA lets you set aside tax-free dollars that can be used toward commuting expenses if you take a bus, train, or van pool to and from work. As with other FSAs, you may decide how much to set aside from your paycheck each week and you are reimbursed for eligible expenses with tax-free dollars.

There are limits as to how much you can contribute to your Transit FSA, established by the IRS, and unlike HSA accounts, only limited amounts of money can be rolled over, although new rules are making fixed amounts transferable if used within a certain time period the following year.

Be sure to estimate the amount of qualified expenses you’re likely to have in a year if you opt for a Transit FSA.

Consult the IRS website for the most up-to-date information on Transit FSA rules, limits, and covered expenses.
advLegalModalText:
A legal plan enables you, your spouse, and your dependents, to access a large network of qualified attorneys. With, advice over the phone and office consultations on a wide range of personal legal matters, your legal plan helps you address events from buying or selling your house, to adopting a child, to preparing your will.


When you use a covered attorney, most legal plans offer:

• No deductibles
• No copays
• No waiting periods
• No claim forms


Consider a legal plan if you anticipate having any of the covered legal expenses this year.
DaysAllowedToMakeLifeEventErrorMessage: You can only submit a {0} life event up to {1} days in the past.
advPetInsuranceModalText:
Pet insurance helps you pay for the medical care your pet needs, from check-ups to catastrophic care. Like the network of doctors and hospitals you see with some medical plans, you’ll take your pet to a participating vet for care. You may have copays, coinsurance, and/or deductibles to meet and you may also need to file claim forms. The plan then pays part of your bill, up to any annual limits.


You can choose pet insurance plans to cover your pet for:

• Accidents, only;
• Both accidents and illnesses; and/or
• Wellness, including annual exams, vaccinations, spaying/neutering surgery, and dental cleanings.

For complete coverage, choose both an illness/accident plan and a wellness plan.
advIdentityTheftModalText:
Identity Theft Protection increases your financial security with ongoing services to:


• Monitor your credit report
• Search thousands of public information databases for data correlated with your Social Security number (SSN)
• Monitor the National Change of Address database
• Check payday loan databases for high interest, quick cash loans taken out in your name
• Send you email or text notices if your information changes
• Work to clear any fraud and restore your good name if a theft occurs


When suspicious changes to your accounts are detected, an Identity Theft Protection service may place fraud alerts on your accounts to stop the activity and contest any fraudulent charges.

A basic Identity Theft Protection plan will monitor one of the nation’s three credit reporting bureaus. A premium plan will monitor all three, increasing the chances of catching incorrect information or fraud.


Depending on your level of credit, spending and online activity, you may require a greater amount of protection against potential fraudulent activity.

advParkingFSAModalText:
A Parking FSA lets you set aside tax-free dollars that can be used toward parking expenses if you drive to work. As with other FSAs, you may decide how much to set aside from your paycheck each week and you are reimbursed for eligible expenses with tax-free dollars.


There are limits as to how much you can contribute to your Parking FSA, established by the IRS, and unlike HSA accounts, you generally cannot roll this money over to the following year, although new rules are making fixed amounts transferable if used within a certain time period the following year.


Be sure to estimate the amount of qualified expenses you’re likely to have in a year if you opt for a Parking FSA.


Consult the IRS website (www.irs.gov) for the most up to date information on Parking FSA rules, limits, and covered expenses.

advEmployeeLifeModalText:
Life insurance is a financial tool that helps you safeguard your family's future. To buy Life insurance, you pay monthly premiums to an insurance company that agrees to pay a specific amount to your designated beneficiaries in the event of your death. You can name a primary beneficiary and a contingent beneficiary who would receive benefits if the primary beneficiary dies before you do.


You should consider Life Insurance if any of these is true:


• You have a spouse, domestic partner, children, or dependent parents
• You have less than $20,000 in liquid savings to pay final medical expenses, funeral and burial
• You have debts, including student loans
• You have a car or home that is not paid for
• You have children who plan on attending college


With Life insurance, you ensure financial resources that go toward:


• Final medical expenses
• Funeral and burial costs
• Mortgage, housing and other bills related to daily life
advHospitalIndemnityModalText: Hospital Indemnity insurance provides a daily defined cash benefit amount in the event that you’re hospitalized. Note that these plans can differ greatly: some require a minimum stay before payments kick in, while others may offer payouts starting with the first day of your hospitalization, so be sure to review plan details carefully. These cash payments can be used to cover co-payments, household expenses, and more.

adv401KModalText:
A 401(k) savings account is a financial vehicle that helps you allocate a portion of your salary each pay period toward retirement. By allowing you to put aside a portion of your income pre-tax, you avoid paying any taxes on the money you contribute. In addition, contributing to your 401(k) account reduces your taxable income, so you may save even more in taxes. Once you're ready to withdraw the money in retirement, you'll pay taxes on it then.

Until you withdraw your savings from your 401(k), you can invest this money in funds selected by your employer and administered by a financial investment firm. If you choose to draw from this account early, you will have to pay a penalty.

You should consider contributing to your 401(k) to supplement your income in retirement. According to the Social Security Administration, Social Security only replaces 40% of the average worker's income after retirement. Chances are, you will need more than that to maintain your standard of living.

You can change the amount you contribute to your 401(k) account at any time. You own your contributions and investment earnings. If you leave your current employer, you'll get to keep this money and can transfer or "roll over" your 401(k) to an account with a new employer or an individual account, if you wish. You will not pay taxes on the money when you roll it over to another account.

Your employer may also contribute to your 401(k). Keep this in mind as you consider how much to invest.
advPersonalLifeModalText:
Personal Life insurance helps you protect your family's future. To buy Personal Life insurance (also called "Individual Life insurance"), you pay monthly premiums to an insurance company that agrees to pay a specific amount to your designated beneficiaries in the event of your death. You can name a primary beneficiary and a contingent beneficiary who would receive benefits if the primary beneficiary dies before you do.


You may be offered Personal Life insurance in addition to a Group Life insurance plan through your employer, and you are eligible to purchase both plans. Personal Life insurance is different than Group Life insurance in that it is portable, meaning that you can take the coverage with you if you leave your employer. While pricing for Group Life insurance policies is negotiated at the group level, Personal Life insurance is priced at the individual level, considering your birthday, health, and other factors. Personal Life insurance typically offers higher levels of coverage than Group Life insurance plans.


You should consider Life Insurance if any of these is true:


• You have a spouse, domestic partner, children, or parents who depend on your income
• You have less than $20,000 in liquid savings to pay for final medical expenses and/or funeral and burial costs
• You have debts, including some private student loans
• You have a car or home that isn't paid for
• You have children who plan to attend college


With Life insurance, you ensure your loved ones have the financial resources to:


• Pay for your final medical expenses
• Pay for your funeral and burial expenses
• Pay mortgage, housing, and other bills related to daily life
advAccidentModalText:
Accident insurance helps to provide you with additional funds that may not be covered by your medical plan if you’re hurt in an accident.


The money can be used for anything you wish including:

• Copays, deductibles, and/or coinsurance
• Travel, including costs for flying in loved ones
• Over-the-counter medicines and physical therapy
• Child or pet care and help around the house


Accident Insurance may include a daily hospital benefit, but there may be a waiting period required before benefits begin if a pre-existing condition contributed to the accident.
advShortTermModalText:
Short Term Disability insurance helps replace a portion of your income when you can't work due to illness or non-work related accident for anywhere from a few weeks to a few months.


When calculating how much Short Term Disability coverage you may need, you should consider:

  • Your savings
  • Your expenses
  • Your spouse's income
  • Your likelihood to be absent from work for an extended period of time

advSpouseLifeModalText:
Spouse Life insurance is a tool that helps you safeguard your family's financial future. To buy Spouse Life insurance, you pay monthly premiums to an insurance company that agrees to pay a specific amount in the event of your spouse’s death. You can name a primary beneficiary and a contingent beneficiary (who would receive benefits if the primary beneficiary dies before your spouse).


You should consider Spouse Life insurance if:


• You have a spouse or domestic partner who contributes income that you rely on


With Spouse Life insurance you can ensure financial resources that go toward:


• Final medical expenses
• Funeral and burial costs
• Mortgage, housing, and other bills related to daily life

You should consider the income your spouse earns, the income your earn, your family's expenses, your current financial situation, including debt and education expenses, and your family's ability to pay for your spouse’s funeral when calculating how much Spouse Life insurance you will need.
advCriticalIllnessModalText:
Critical Illness insurance help you meet expenses such as copays, coinsurance, and deductibles if you develop one of the conditions covered in the plan, including cancer, heart attack, or stroke, among others.


You may need to submit a diagnosis, pathology report, or evidence of hospital admission before you receive a lump sum payment. It’s important to pay attention to the plan details to determine which diseases are covered, as well as when and how the benefits go into effect.
advDentalModalText:
Dental insurance helps you pay for regular dental checkups and some restorative treatments. Plans vary in how they deliver care and how much they pay. A dental plan will cover preventive care, such as:

  • Scheduled Dental Exams
  • X-rays
  • Cleanings

A plan may also cover:

  • Cavity fillings
  • Tooth extractions
  • Services to restore damaged teeth
  • Bridgework and dentures
  • Orthodontia (braces)


Some dental plans require a waiting period before the plan will cover major dental services, such as fillings or crowns. Also, with some plans, you need to coordinate your care through a primary dentist. Such plans may save you money, however, as with an HMO for medical care.


When you enroll in a dental plan, consider enrolling in a health FSA or HSA, too. These accounts give you a tax break on money you set aside for out-of-pocket health care expenses, including dental bills.
advEmployerPaidSTDModalText:
Short Term Disability insurance helps replace a portion of your income when you can't work due to illness or non-work related accident for anywhere from a few weeks to a few months. Your employer has chosen to provide some STD insurance coverage to you at no cost. However, you need to assess if this coverage is sufficient for your needs.

You may have access to several tiers of Short Term Disability insurance should you need to take time off of work due to sickness or injury.

When calculating how much Short Term Disability coverage you may need, you should consider:

• Your savings
• Your expenses
• Your spouse’s income
• Your likelihood to be absent from work for an extended period of time
advAdviceText: Selecting the right benefits package for you and your dependents can provide financial protection against unforeseen risks. Some coverage types protect you from a larger potential financial exposure than others. As you select your benefits, we recommend considering those that can have the greatest financial impact first, and then considering other coverages.
advLongTermText: Long Term Disability insurance helps to off-set a portion of your income in the event you're unable to work for an extended period of time. Selecting the right amount of coverage is important.
advAccidentText: Accident insurance provides you with money to cover unexpected costs you may incur in the event of an accident, such as child care expenses, bills, or even transportation.
advCriticalIllnessText: Critical Illness insurance provides a lump sum payment if you're diagnosed with a covered critical illness such as cancer, heart attack, or stroke. Covered illnesses may vary.
advSpouseLifeText: Spouse Life insurance provides a one-time payout in the event of the death of your spouse. This is important if you and your family depend on your spouse's income to maintain your lifestyle.
advShortTermText: Short Term Disability insurance helps to offset some portion of the salary you may lose should you find yourself out of work temporarily on disability leave.
advVisionText: Vision insurance can help to cover the cost of eye exams, eyeglasses, and contact lenses.
AdvTelemedicineText: Telemedicine plans allow you to use phone, smartphone or other internet-enabled device, depending on the plan, to speak to a doctor who can help diagnose and prescribe medication for a range of ailments — from a sinus infection in the middle of the night to ongoing patient monitoring.
advHealthSavingsText: A Health Savings Account (HSA) allows you to contribute tax-free money each year that you can use to help pay for expenses such as prescriptions, deductibles, and co-pays. HSAs are usually offered in conjunction with qualified high-deductible medical plans.
advPetInsuranceText: Pet insurance helps to cover both routine health care maintenance and emergency expenses for your pet.
advChildLifeText: Child Life insurance provides a one-time payout in the event of the death of a child. Select plans may also cover funeral expenses.
advLegalText: Legal Plans allow you to save money when you prepay for legal expenses that you may use throughout the year, such as updating a will or buying a home. A legal plan helps you gain access to a qualified attorney to assist you with these services.
advIdentityTheftText: An Identify Theft Protection plan monitors your accounts for theft activity and may also help to provide assistance in the event they're compromised.
advPersonalTimeText: Personal Time Off (PTO) allows you to set aside money through payroll deductions or apply part of your employer's defined contribution toward purchasing additional time off from work.
advMedicalFSAText: A Medical Flexible Spending Account (FSA) allows you to set aside pre-tax money from your paychecks that you can use to pay for qualified medical expenses, everything from your copays to your new glasses to bandages.
advDependentFSAText: A Dependent Care Flexible Spending Account (FSA) allows you to set aside pre-tax money from your paychecks that you can use to pay for childcare related expenses, such as babysitters and daycare, or other expenses.
advTransitFSAText: A Transit Flexible Spending Account (FSA) allows you to set aside pre-tax money from your paychecks that you can use to pay for commuting expenses if you take the bus or train, vanpool or even bike to work.
advParkingFSAText: A Parking Flexible Spending Account (FSA) allows you to set aside pre-tax money from your paychecks that you can use to pay for parking expenses if you drive to work. Learn more here.
advHealthCareCostsText: Health care costs for standard tests and procedures can vary greatly. Using a healthcare transparency tool can help you find the most cost-effective and high-quality facilities that are the best fit for the services you need.
advHealthCoachText: Health Coaching provides you a range of either online services or event an experienced coach who helps you with a range of health-related activities, from choosing the right foods, to exercise and dealing with stress.
advMedicalModalText:
From preventive care to doctor's visits to emergency surgery, a medical plan helps you pay the cost of planned and unplanned medical events. You may have a range of medical plan options available to you; learn how each type of plan works and manages expenses. Choose the one that fits your needs — and your budget — balancing things like premium cost with deductible amounts, co-pays, and more.


An "in-network" provider is a physician, hospital, clinic, or group of health care professionals that has contracted with a Health Maintenance Organization (HMO) or Preferred Provider Organization (PPO) to provide health care services at a pre-negotiated, discounted rate. In-Network Only plans can vary in terms of network size, providers, costs, deductibles, out-of-pocket expenses, and copays. Be sure to compare plans and review the provider directory if you have doctors or providers you would like to continue seeing. In-network only plans do not cover expenses from out of network providers.


Carefully consider whom you should cover. If your spouse or partner is offered benefits through their job, it may be to your financial advantage to enroll in your benefits separately. Also, note the "age-off" limit for dependents. Plans typically cover children up to age 26, but rules may vary by plan. Refer to the IRS website for the definition of "dependent" if you have questions about older children or other dependent relatives who may be eligible for coverage.


If an HSA-qualified plan appears in your store display: A Health Savings Account (HSA), when combined with a qualified medical plan, allows you to contribute money each year that can be used to help pay for qualified medical expenses such as prescription drugs, deductibles, and copays. HSAs are paired with high deductible health plans to help offset costs incurred before a deductible is met, as well as out-of-pocket costs. Any unused funding rolls over from year-to-year. You should strongly consider an HSA if you select an HSA-qualified plan and anticipate having out-of-pocket costs, including your deductible.


A Primary Care Physician (PCP) plan requires you to designate a Primary Care Physician who will be the gatekeeper for your medical referrals. If a health problem arises, your PCP sees you first and then, if necessary, refers you to an in-network specialist. These plans are often less expensive than other health plans. If you don't mind getting referrals, you may want to consider this type of plan.


If multiple plans appear in your store display: Choosing the right health plan can be confusing with variables such as network, deductible amount, and coinsurance all factoring into your decision. You can use the Compare Plans tool to help weigh plan options against these and other variables. Visit our help center for helpful definitions of common insurance plan terms and information about choosing plans that are right for you.
advHighestText: These coverage types help to protect you against events that can have the most impact on your long-term financial health. These are the most important risks to cover.
advLongTermModalText:
Long Term Disability insurance helps replace a portion of your income when you can't work due to a disability over an extended period of time. There are several tiers of coverage available — choose the level of protection that fits your needs and your budget.

When calculating how much Long Term Disability insurance coverage you may need, you should consider:

  • Your savings
  • Your expenses
  • Your spouse’s income
  • Your likelihood to be absent from work for an extended or prolonged period of time
adv401KText: A 401(k) Retirement Savings Account helps you save for retirement by allowing you to contribute a portion of your paycheck pre-tax.
advModerateText: These coverage types help to protect you against events that can have a significant impact on your financial health, especially in the short term.
advLowestText: These coverage types help to protect you against both planned and unplanned expenses. They may also save you money through tax-free savings accounts.
advMedicalText: Medical insurance can provide coverage for everything from routine physical exams to unexpected hospital stays. Medical plans vary.
advEmployeeLifeText: Life insurance helps provide for your loved ones in the event of your passing. Choosing the right amount of coverage is important.
advSeeHow: See how Disability Insurance helped protect Bill's income (3-minutes)
advDentalText: Dental Insurance can cover everything from regular dental exams and cleanings to orthodontic or restorative work. Plan benefits may vary.

privacyOtherColSub2: Using cookies:  Cookies are pieces of information stored directly on the computer that you are using.  Cookies allow us to collect information such as browser type, time spent on the Services, pages visited, language preferences, and other anonymous traffic data.  We and our service providers use the information for security purposes, to facilitate navigation, and to recognize your computer in order to assist your use of the Services.  We also gather statistical information about use of the Services in order to continually improve their design and functionality, understand how they are used and assist us with resolving questions regarding them.   If you disable cookies on the site, the site may not function properly.
privacyOtherColSub3: IP Address:  Your IP address is a number that is automatically assigned to the computer that you are using by your Internet Service Provider (ISP).  An IP address may be identified and logged automatically in our server log files whenever a user accesses the Services, along with the time of the visit and the page(s) that were visited.  Collecting IP addresses is standard practice and is done automatically by many websites, applications and other services.  We use IP addresses for purposes such as calculating usage levels, diagnosing server problems and administering the Services.  We may also derive your approximate location from your IP address.
